comment_text.mn134:1.3: Lomasakaṅgiya’s verse speaks of his determination to forge his way through the dense jungle in search of seclusion (Thag 1.27). He is probably also the same monk who appears in SN 54.12. His name means “hairy-limbs”.
comment_text.mn134:2.1: The god Candana, whose name means “sandalwood”, also appears at DN 20:10.5, DN 32:10.4, and SN 2:2.15.
comment_text.mn134:2.11: This suggests that Candana was one of the Thirty-three. In the Chinese parallels, however, he heard this at Rājagaha. | Paṇḍukambala is a kind of luxury upholstery.
comment_text.mn134:6.4: Candana is here praised for his skill in learning, yet earlier he says that although he was present when the Buddha taught the “recitation passage and analysis”, he only remembered the verses (MN 134:2.12). As at MN 133:6.2, the parallels are more coherent, as they only mention him hearing the verses.
comment_text.mn134:8-13.1: The Buddha goes on to repeat the analysis as in MN 131:4.1ff.

root_text.mn134:1.2: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṁ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.

root_text.mn134:2.10: “Yathā kathaṁ pana tvaṁ, āvuso, dhāresi bhaddekarattiyo gāthā”ti?

root_text.mn134:5.1: Atha kho āyasmā lomasakaṅgiyo tassā rattiyā accayena senāsanaṁ saṁsāmetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena sāvatthi tena cārikaṁ pakkāmi.
root_text.mn134:5.2: Anupubbena cārikaṁ caramāno yena sāvatthi jetavanaṁ anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāmo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho āyasmā lomasakaṅgiyo bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn134:5.3: “Ekamidāhaṁ, bhante, samayaṁ sakkesu viharāmi kapilavatthusmiṁ nigrodhārāme.
root_text.mn134:5.4: Atha kho, bhante, aññataro devaputto abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇo kevalakappaṁ nigrodhārāmaṁ obhāsetvā yenāhaṁ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā ekamantaṁ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṁ ṭhito kho, bhante, so devaputto maṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn134:5.6: Evaṁ vutte, ahaṁ, bhante, taṁ devaputtaṁ etadavocaṁ:

root_text.mn134:6.4: Candano, bhikkhu, devaputto aṭṭhiṁ katvā manasikatvā sabbacetasā samannāharitvā ohitasoto dhammaṁ suṇāti.
root_text.mn134:6.5: Tena hi, bhikkhu, suṇāhi, sādhukaṁ manasi karohi; bhāsissāmī”ti.

translation_text.mn134:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
translation_text.mn134:1.3: Now at that time Venerable Lomasakaṅgiya was staying in the Sakyan country at Kapilavatthu in the Banyan Tree Monastery.
translation_text.mn134:2.1: Then, late at night, the glorious godling Candana, lighting up the entire Banyan Tree Monastery, went up to the Venerable Lomasakaṅgiya, and stood to one side. Standing to one side, he said to Lomasakaṅgiya:
translation_text.mn134:2.2: “Mendicant, do you remember the summary recital and the analysis of the one who has one fine night?”
translation_text.mn134:2.6: But do you remember just the verses on the one who has one fine night?”
translation_text.mn134:2.10: “How do you remember the verses on the one who has one fine night?”
translation_text.mn134:2.11: “This one time, the Buddha was staying among the gods of the thirty-three at the root of the Shady Orchid Tree on the stone spread with a cream rug.
translation_text.mn134:2.12: There he taught the summary recital and the analysis of the one who has one fine night to the gods of the thirty-three:
translation_text.mn134:3.6: you clearly discern in every case.
translation_text.mn134:3.9: Today’s the day to keenly work—
translation_text.mn134:3.10: who knows, tomorrow may bring death!
translation_text.mn134:3.11: For there is no bargain to be struck
translation_text.mn134:3.12: with Death and his mighty horde.
translation_text.mn134:3.13: One who keenly meditates like this,
translation_text.mn134:3.15: that’s who has one fine night—
translation_text.mn134:4.1: That’s how I remember the verses of the one who has one fine night.
translation_text.mn134:4.2: Learn the summary recital and the analysis of the one who has one fine night, mendicant,
translation_text.mn134:4.5: It is beneficial and relevant to the fundamentals of the spiritual life.”
translation_text.mn134:4.6: That’s what the godling Candana said
translation_text.mn134:5.1: Then Lomasakaṅgiya set his lodgings in order and, taking his bowl and robe, set out for Sāvatthī.
translation_text.mn134:5.2: Eventually he came to Sāvatthī and Jeta’s Grove. He went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened. Then he added:
translation_text.mn134:5.28: “Sir, please teach me the summary recital and the analysis of the one who has one fine night.”
translation_text.mn134:6.1: “But mendicant, do you know that god?”
translation_text.mn134:6.4: Candana pays attention, applies the mind, concentrates wholeheartedly, and actively listens to the teaching.
translation_text.mn134:6.5: Well then, mendicant, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
translation_text.mn134:7.6: you clearly discern in every case.
translation_text.mn134:7.9: Today’s the day to keenly work—
translation_text.mn134:7.10: who knows, tomorrow may bring death!
translation_text.mn134:7.11: For there is no bargain to be struck
translation_text.mn134:7.12: with Death and his mighty horde.
translation_text.mn134:7.13: One who keenly meditates like this,
translation_text.mn134:7.15: that’s who has one fine night—
translation_text.mn134:8-13.1: And how do you run back to the past? … ”
translation_text.mn134:14.17: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.mn134:14.18: Satisfied, Venerable Lomasakaṅgiya approved what the Buddha said.
